document_identifier.description:
This is for convenience: the first identifier that was ever used to refer to a 
document is kept here. Internally the centrifuge node indexes & bundles documents 
by original identifier.

32 byte value

current_identifier.description:
The current identifier is the location of the current anchor on chain and is used to 
refer to the current state.

32 byte value

next_identifier.description: When creating the next version this should be used.

previous_versions.title:
The previous document is referenced here but doesn't need to be provided and can
be left blank

coredocumentCoreDocument.description:
* Merkle Roots for the document data
* Signatures on document data
* Access Control
coredocumentCoreDocument.title:
`CoreDocument` is a document that can be sent to different nodes and anchored 
on chain. It handles all the generic features native Centrifuge Documents support:

entity_id.description: `entity_id` is the CentrifugeID of the entity signing the document.

public_key.title: `public_key` is the public key of the `entity` used for signing the `CoreDocument`

coredocumentSignature.title: Signature contains the entity ID, public key used and signature)

invoiceInvoiceData.title: InvoiceData is the default invoice schema

recipients.title: Centrifuge OS Entity of the recipient

type_url.description:
A URL/resource name whose content describes the type of the
serialized protocol buffer message.

For URLs which use the scheme `http`, `https`, or no scheme, the
following restrictions and interpretations apply:

* If no scheme is provided, `https` is assumed.
* The last segment of the URL's path must represent the fully
  qualified name of the type (as in `path/google.protobuf.Duration`).
  The name should be in a canonical form (e.g., leading "." is
  not accepted).
* An HTTP GET on the URL must yield a [google.protobuf.Type][]
  value in binary format, or produce an error.
* Applications are allowed to cache lookup results based on the
  URL, or have them precompiled into a binary to avoid any
  lookup. Therefore, binary compatibility needs to be preserved
  on changes to types. (Use versioned type names to manage
  breaking changes.)

Schemes other than `http`, `https` (or the empty scheme) might be
used with implementation specific semantics.

value.description: Must be a valid serialized protocol buffer of the above specified type.

post.description: Creates a list of precise proofs for the specified fields
Send an invoice document to the specified party
